comment:
Great discussion guys. I love the fact that you have identified the need of absolute moral values what an AGI should abide. I understand that this will evolve with the training data and feedback therefore at large scale should reflect the pulse of the humanity. I have asked Chat GPT this and the answer is amazingly well thought :           " Sure, here is a summary of some recommended absolute moral rules that could include sentient beings along with humans:

Respect for life: All living beings, including humans and animals, should be treated with respect and their lives should be valued.

Non-violence: The use of violence or harm towards other living beings should be avoided as much as possible.

Compassion: Practicing compassion towards all living beings, and seeking to reduce suffering whenever possible.

Justice and fairness: Treating all beings equitably and fairly, without discrimination or favoritism.

Responsibility: Taking responsibility for the impact of one's actions on other living beings and the environment, and seeking to minimize harm.

Sustainability: Ensuring that actions are sustainable and do not deplete resources or harm the environment for future generations of all living beings.

Education: Seeking to educate oneself and others about the value of all living beings and how to treat them with respect and compassion.

It's worth noting that these moral rules are not necessarily exhaustive or universally accepted, and different cultures and individuals may have their own specific moral codes. However, they can provide a starting point for considering how to integrate ethical considerations for sentient beings into a broader moral framework that includes humans."

comment: Quite interesting. A take away is that according to Sam "math is the truth" so they may be using some formal verification to check that the model do what it is meant to do. When roles switch and the model is the one able to check for correctness and the "truth", that  will be a pivotal point for AI. The truth is in a way a dynamic construction based on human knowledge, so when the model is able to produce new knowledge in fundamental research areas, we will be replaced. Meanwhile there are millions of humans still without access to electricity, internet, and so on. For them AI means nothing.

comment: I do not have any information on the skincare routine of Sam Altman. As an AI language model, I have access to a vast amount of information on a wide range of topics, including entrepreneurship, technology, and artificial intelligence. However, personal information, such as skincare routines, is generally not publicly available, and it is not appropriate for me to speculate or provide information that is not supported by reliable sources.
author: @resumefacts

comment:
As an AI language model, my responses are generated based on the text input that I receive, without making assumptions about the age or background of the user. I am designed to provide informative and helpful responses to users of all ages and backgrounds, and I try to use language that is clear, concise, and easy to understand.

That being said, it is important for users to understand that while I can provide information and assistance, I am a machine and do not have the ability to fully comprehend human emotions or experiences. Therefore, it is always important to seek advice from trusted sources and to use one's own judgment when making important decisions or taking action based on the information provided.
author: @resumefacts

author: @thomasflood5268

comment:
The foremost menace to the contemporary world lies in the prospect of AI facilitating clarity in traditionally uncertain domains such as investment. In this regard, the speculative aspect may become obsolete, with a potential worst-case scenario being that it becomes a battleground for AI bots. Such developments may have undesirable consequences for the world at large. Nonetheless, we must not delude ourselves into thinking that anything can forestall this outcome. Regardless of whether GPT is open-sourced or not, greater funds are currently invested in ongoing methods. I am convinced that AI is already operational but its disclosure is unfeasible due to the essential role of trust in investment, which must not be undermined.

I surmise that AI will make its public entry into the world of finance as the last player, albeit in reality, it will have been the first.

author: @UC4o8gkoFHTiq

comment:
By the way, physics is not "the truth" as commonly understood. 

TLDR: Physics doesn't significantly contribute to the accuracy or "truthness" already supplied by the underlying math.

Rather, it is a mathematical approximation of the external world as we perceive it. As such, while it is a useful tool, it is not entirely accurate. Physics, as a science in isolation (without practical application), is indeed as accurate as we can imagine, but when it is without real-world part, it is reduced to a purely mathematical concept - the math. ;-)
author: @xuldevelopers

author: @dash5938

classify_comment: critical examination of the use of AGI in democracy
comment:
Democracy governed by AGI? This presents a notable example of how IT professionals may lack insight into societal matters. 

It is unlikely to transpire for various reasons, primarily due to the fact that no democratically elected individual at the helm would be inclined to heed a machine. If one occupies a position of decision-making, one can anticipate an inclination to quash any mechanisms that limit one's power of decision, including, among others, AGI. One would, therefore, endeavor to employ all methods sanctioned by society to augment one's leadership role, one of which is already manifest in the deployment of AI systems to regulate the populace in the guise of security.

In essence, AGI may not lead democracy, but instead, it will be used to control it. Such control could result in a considerable increase in societal efficiency; however, it also has its pitfalls. Very dark ones.

comment: It's not intelligent, yet.  It is "artificial" intelligence.  Just like a calculator can solve math problems better than most people.  GPT-4 is no different with respect to that,  it is just able to solve a lot more than a calculator can.  It is a pattern based NN with billions of parameters.  How it solves things is not fully understood like a calculator, but there is no solid proof that this "black box" will ever become intelligent.  Just saying, in it's current state - it should not be terrifying.

comment: Guys, I really enjoyed your conversation. But what leaves me puzzled is the idea of AI governance and a human AI ethics committee. Currently in many countries there are laws about what can be said and what not. These are clarified and disputed in law cases and court decisions. All of that is (mostly) publicly available. Written in a hard to understand language, at least for the average human. But this task should be fairly easy for a large language model. Why do you see a need for additional structures and rules when not even the current ones are incorporated yet?
author: @larslepik

author: @Smile5098

comment:
​@The_LexFridman.. 

In addition to AI not having the ability to think and comprehend.  I'm just not so sure about the potential of AI technology.   There are serious problems.  AI is not perfect.  GPT-4 is awesome, but it makes mistakes and that is fine,  but most real world applications require perfection that AI has yet to offer. 

That sounds like a trivial problem, but It is not.  Ai can't be trusted and that is why people still have jobs.  Some people predicted a decade ago that this would not be the case.  In spite of an insane amount of processing power since then,  millions of AI developers world wide, it's still a problem.  Why?  Also consider what it took to develop GPT-4.  I think ChatGPT is fun...I'm not threatened by it.  Now there is talk to pause AI development, but we have a long way to go, IMO.
author: @windowstrainingmodules
